text:
Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests. However, I do not believe it is reasonable nor practical for many citizens to be informed about all events that are currently happening in the world.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests. However, I do not believe it is reasonable nor practical for many citizens to be informed about all events that are currently happening in the world. There is simply too much information out there, about every issue and event that may come into existence.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests. However, I do not believe it is reasonable nor practical for many citizens to be informed about all events that are currently happening in the world. There is simply too much information out there, about every issue and event that may come into existence. In addition, the prevalence of misinformation and false news makes it quite difficult for people to engage with and learn more about certain topics. In that sense, it is not wrong for a person to be selective on what kind of news they follow or chose to engage with, as long as they can be flexible in their thinking, and be open for discussion when others wish to inform them of key events occurring in the world. 

As for

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests. However, I do not believe it is reasonable nor practical for many citizens to be informed about all events that are currently happening in the world. There is simply too much information out there, about every issue and event that may come into existence. In addition, the prevalence of misinformation and false news makes it quite difficult for people to engage with and learn more about certain topics. In that sense, it is not wrong for a person to be selective on what kind of news they follow or chose to engage with, as long as they can be flexible in their thinking, and be open for discussion when others wish to inform them of key events occurring in the world. 

As for our responsibility to engage with current events, I'd think it is paramount, at least to some extent.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests. However, I do not believe it is reasonable nor practical for many citizens to be informed about all events that are currently happening in the world. There is simply too much information out there, about every issue and event that may come into existence. In addition, the prevalence of misinformation and false news makes it quite difficult for people to engage with and learn more about certain topics. In that sense, it is not wrong for a person to be selective on what kind of news they follow or chose to engage with, as long as they can be flexible in their thinking, and be open for discussion when others wish to inform them of key events occurring in the world. 

As for our responsibility to engage with current events, I'd think it is paramount, at least to some extent. Without the majority of people engaging with current events, which includes spreading awareness of them, I believe many current issues and problems that exist in the world would go unnoticed, and effectively uncontested.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests. However, I do not believe it is reasonable nor practical for many citizens to be informed about all events that are currently happening in the world. There is simply too much information out there, about every issue and event that may come into existence. In addition, the prevalence of misinformation and false news makes it quite difficult for people to engage with and learn more about certain topics. In that sense, it is not wrong for a person to be selective on what kind of news they follow or chose to engage with, as long as they can be flexible in their thinking, and be open for discussion when others wish to inform them of key events occurring in the world. 

As for our responsibility to engage with current events, I'd think it is paramount, at least to some extent. Without the majority of people engaging with current events, which includes spreading awareness of them, I believe many current issues and problems that exist in the world would go unnoticed, and effectively uncontested. It is absolutely crucial to engage and talk about topics and events occurring in the world so we, as a group, may come to a consensus and create an optimal solution towards the problems that affect the people of the world. Given the prevalence and widespread use of social media and modern forms of communication, I believe many people can spread the means to get people engaged with current events.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests. However, I do not believe it is reasonable nor practical for many citizens to be informed about all events that are currently happening in the world. There is simply too much information out there, about every issue and event that may come into existence. In addition, the prevalence of misinformation and false news makes it quite difficult for people to engage with and learn more about certain topics. In that sense, it is not wrong for a person to be selective on what kind of news they follow or chose to engage with, as long as they can be flexible in their thinking, and be open for discussion when others wish to inform them of key events occurring in the world. 

As for our responsibility to engage with current events, I'd think it is paramount, at least to some extent. Without the majority of people engaging with current events, which includes spreading awareness of them, I believe many current issues and problems that exist in the world would go unnoticed, and effectively uncontested. It is absolutely crucial to engage and talk about topics and events occurring in the world so we, as a group, may come to a consensus and create an optimal solution towards the problems that affect the people of the world. Given the prevalence and widespread use of social media and modern forms of communication, I believe many people can spread the means to get people engaged with current events. I have seen this first hand, through major events that were first reported via social media, such as natural disasters or political events with people asking others for assistance in a multitude of ways.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests. However, I do not believe it is reasonable nor practical for many citizens to be informed about all events that are currently happening in the world. There is simply too much information out there, about every issue and event that may come into existence. In addition, the prevalence of misinformation and false news makes it quite difficult for people to engage with and learn more about certain topics. In that sense, it is not wrong for a person to be selective on what kind of news they follow or chose to engage with, as long as they can be flexible in their thinking, and be open for discussion when others wish to inform them of key events occurring in the world. 

As for our responsibility to engage with current events, I'd think it is paramount, at least to some extent. Without the majority of people engaging with current events, which includes spreading awareness of them, I believe many current issues and problems that exist in the world would go unnoticed, and effectively uncontested. It is absolutely crucial to engage and talk about topics and events occurring in the world so we, as a group, may come to a consensus and create an optimal solution towards the problems that affect the people of the world. Given the prevalence and widespread use of social media and modern forms of communication, I believe many people can spread the means to get people engaged with current events. I have seen this first hand, through major events that were first reported via social media, such as natural disasters or political events with people asking others for assistance in a multitude of ways. 

In terms of whether engaging with current events results in anything, I'll say that it has the potential to do so.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests. However, I do not believe it is reasonable nor practical for many citizens to be informed about all events that are currently happening in the world. There is simply too much information out there, about every issue and event that may come into existence. In addition, the prevalence of misinformation and false news makes it quite difficult for people to engage with and learn more about certain topics. In that sense, it is not wrong for a person to be selective on what kind of news they follow or chose to engage with, as long as they can be flexible in their thinking, and be open for discussion when others wish to inform them of key events occurring in the world. 

As for our responsibility to engage with current events, I'd think it is paramount, at least to some extent. Without the majority of people engaging with current events, which includes spreading awareness of them, I believe many current issues and problems that exist in the world would go unnoticed, and effectively uncontested. It is absolutely crucial to engage and talk about topics and events occurring in the world so we, as a group, may come to a consensus and create an optimal solution towards the problems that affect the people of the world. Given the prevalence and widespread use of social media and modern forms of communication, I believe many people can spread the means to get people engaged with current events. I have seen this first hand, through major events that were first reported via social media, such as natural disasters or political events with people asking others for assistance in a multitude of ways. In terms of whether engaging with current events results in anything, I'll say that has and will still be able to do so for future occurrences. Even if some that learn about the news chose to do nothing about it, there will always be others that take the initiative to do something about the issue.

Are We Being Bad Citizens If We Don't Keep Up With the News?

In your opinion, are we being bad citizens if we don't keep up with the news? Do you think all people have some responsibility to know what is going on in the world? Does engaging with current events actually do anything at all? Why do you think the way you do?

---

I believe it is ideal that citizens should be informed with current news to some extent. It gives more awareness on what's going on and enables us to make better judgements and more educated decisions regarding issues, events and other things that may impact us in a significant manner. In addition, having many citizens keep up with the news allows important issues to be noticed by the collective population, and allow many to join together as a group to voice our concerns and/or opinions regarding those issues, as is the case with most protests. However, I do not believe it is reasonable nor practical for many citizens to be informed about all events that are currently happening in the world. There is simply too much information out there, about every issue and event that may come into existence. In addition, the prevalence of misinformation and false news makes it quite difficult for people to engage with and learn more about certain topics. In that sense, it is not wrong for a person to be selective on what kind of news they follow or chose to engage with, as long as they can be flexible in their thinking, and be open for discussion when others wish to inform them of key events occurring in the world. 

As for our responsibility to engage with current events, I'd think it is paramount, at least to some extent. Without the majority of people engaging with current events, which includes spreading awareness of them, I believe many current issues and problems that exist in the world would go unnoticed, and effectively uncontested. It is absolutely crucial to engage and talk about topics and events occurring in the world so we, as a group, may come to a consensus and create an optimal solution towards the problems that affect the people of the world. Given the prevalence and widespread use of social media and modern forms of communication, I believe many people can spread the means to get people engaged with current events. I have seen this first hand, through major events that were first reported via social media, such as natural disasters or political events with people asking others for assistance in a multitude of ways. In terms of whether engaging with current events results in anything, I'll say that has and will still be able to do so for future occurrences. Even if some that learn about the news chose to do nothing about it, there will always be others that take the initiative to do something about the issue. There will be citizens that take the extra step through protests, donations, volunteering, and much more when they engage with current news, beyond just learning about it. While citizens that don't keep up with current events aren't necessarily bad citizens, it is those that take further steps to change the world for the better along with keeping up with current events that makes them good citizens in my opinion.
